A map is a relationship between two sets that associates every element in one set(domain) to exactly one element in another set (codomain).

Let $K$ be a field (or, more generally, an integral domain) and let $\varphi: \mathbb{Z} \longrightarrow K$ be the canonical ring homomorphism. Furthermore, let $p \in \mathbb{N}$ be a generating element of the principal ideal $\operatorname{ker} \varphi$. Then $p$ is called the characteristic of $K$, and we write $p=\operatorname{char} K$.
Does the concept of a/an Map/Function need to be defined for a definition of a/an Characteristic of a field to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation: The definition of the characteristic of a field involves the concept of a canonical ring homomorphism, which is a specific type of function or map. This homomorphism, denoted as \(\varphi: \mathbb{Z} \longrightarrow K\), maps elements from the set of integers (\(\mathbb{Z}\)) to the field \(K\). The characteristic of the field \(K\) is defined based on the properties of this map, specifically the principal ideal generated by the kernel of \(\varphi\), which is a subset of \(\mathbb{Z}\) mapped to zero in \(K\). Therefore, understanding and defining this map is crucial to defining the characteristic of a field, as it directly uses the concept of a function to establish the relationship between \(\mathbb{Z}\) and \(K\) and to determine the kernel which is central to finding the characteristic.
